reviewText: Please continue to release future volumes.  I am so happy that "THIS IS TOM JONES" show from 1969-71 is finally available on DVD.  I enjoy the show just as much if not more now than I did when it first appeared on  television.  It would be great to release at least 2 more volumes before the summer.2/21/08:  I just viewed the set.  Tom Jones performance of Ray Charles hit "Baby What I'D Say" is incredible.  His moves on stage defy the laws of gravity.  This is a must buy for any Tom Jones Fan.  Also his best version of "I Can't Stop Loving You" that I ever heard him perform.  The appearances of Tony Bennet, Sammy Davis Jr., Bobby Darin, Jerry Lee Lewis, Johnny Cash and Blood Sweet and Tears make this collection a collectors classic.  I am still looking forward to future sets were he performs hits such as "Delilah" "Daughter of Darkness", I'm Coming Home, the entire version of It's Not Unusual" and some of the old standards such as "That Ole Black Magic" " "Autume Leaves" etc... Tom Jones could belt out a song with such raw energy.  I think he was at the peak of his vocal prowess during this early phase of his career.  TIME LIFE:  DON'T STOP NOW!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am pleased I own this latest DVD set.  Tom sings a few incredible songs...."I Can't Stop Loving You", "You'll Never Walk Alone", "Without Love", "I Who Have Nothing" and "Mr. Bojangles" while Sammy Davis dances behind him!The sound and picture quality was not as good as I expected.  I give those two items 3 stars..."average".  Tom's vocal abilities were incredible.  This is an easy DVD set to review.  If you are a life long Tom Jones fan...this is a must purchase.I am hopeful they release at least one more DVD set from his old TV series....so that I can watch him sing "I'm Coming Home" one more time....before I die myself!  He sang it on that show but they have not included it in the previous three DVD sets they have already released?Hey Tom....give us old "ballad fans" what we all want!  You singing the best ballads of your career at the top of your (vocal) career!
summary: He sure was incredible back then....
Title: N/A

reviewText: I vaguely remember the old TV series but as i've gotten older i now appreciate real talent more and Tom Jones is without a doubt the best male vocalist i've ever heard. With power, range and style he can do vocally what others marvel at. I should know i am a vocalist too. These DVD's capture snippets of a time long gone (late 60's early 70's), some humorous and wacky yet most importantly it captures classical musical moments with many legends. In and through it all Tom can out-sing them all and shows off why he is "The Voice". If you want to go back in time and experience real talent instead of today's vocal synthesized nonsense then get these DVD's. I love mine.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ..69 - 71, a fascinating era for me having been born around the time.  I like to look at what people were doing and where they were at at that time.  Not to mention I like the music.  The best thing about this show is the guests..  Blood, Sweat & Tears have a nice spot.  Although the duet with Tom and their lead singer is kind of hokey - not quite Tom's element I guess, but he doesn't take it too seriously. Blood Sweat & Tears singer man he can sing. Tom does a great job with Diahann Carroll - she's a knockout.  And now I just finished watching Liza Minnelli's cover of the Billie Holiday Tune "God Bless The Child".  I'm still catching my breath.  Incredible rendition of the song not to mention Liza is at her sexiest best.  What I love about this show is seeing everybody at this moment in time, and actually not so long ago, but how things have changed and where everybody was then.  Definitely got the Woodstock era lingering in the background, the show itself is more big band schmalzy lounge stuff, dance numbers etc - all of which are well produced, entertaining and all the more interesting for the pop vibe culture creeping through it. You can see the show trying to appeal to both the older generation AND the younger hip generation, AND of course THE GIRLS who all love Tom.  However, this DVD set is a stunning bargain whether you like Tom Jones or not.

reviewText: Personally I was very happy with both of these volumes, as well as the single disc titled what's new pussycat, Admittedly I would have felt cheated if i had paid full price for these, but being able to buy them all, a total 7 discs for about 35 dollars," some i bought in a store and 1 elsewhere on the web, When i purchased these i did not think this was complete, and to be honest I have only recently discovered this very underrated singer and entertainer. Thank god for Vinyl, His Live records are exceptional.The its not unusual opening is easy skipped , just like you skip the opening on dallas or all in the family, Frankly I can believe that big of a deal is being made about that. If you want ,you can pick anything apart if you look hard enough. If your creative, you can get all these dvd's at a bargain rate, and 7 dvd's full of great music. is better than no dvd's. the Little Richard vol 1 set is spine tingling. Little Richard is workin hard !!!, Look at the sweat pouring off his Forehead. The janis joplin vol 1 performance is also killer, Joe Cocker. Moody Blues. all Great.
summary: Was very happy, though i do understand the complaints

reviewText: Tom is the greatest....he endures for all time.  This is such a wonderful trip down memory lane.  So many impressive guest stars!  These DVD's offer a glimps into another, older decade and the man who was destined to be a super star.  The VOICE lives!!!!!

reviewText: Even when these sets are not complete they are still so nostalgic and entertaining and it shows how good TV was in those days. In these sets you will see some great performances by artist like "Johnny Cash" "Tony Bennett" "Liza Minelli" "Blood, Sweat & Tears" "Sammy Davis Jr" "Bobby Darin" among others and some good comedy sketches as well. Have all three "This is Tom Jones" releases and can't wait for Time Life to release some more.
summary: Not Complete Yet Nostalgic and Entertaining

reviewText: Back in the good ol' days of TV, critics and viewers would say How come Milton Berles' gotta be in every scene? Comedy to him was an uncontrollable impulse - we appreciate and understand that today. Years later, on This Is Tom Jones, folks remarked that he was too dominant on the medleys done with guests - yeah, he shoulda laid back just a taste in harmony mode not in call-and-response mode. But how can you contain a guy whose love of music, whose artistic exuberance defied all laws of physics. Forgot to add, the man who brought Opera to Pop, or at least continued the tradition started by Jackie Wilson, Roy Orbison, and Jay Black. (Elvis Presley had his moments, too, in this endeavour). They really could have saved on amplification.For years me and a good buddy ruminated on the great void created by *zero* VHS representation of the super-dude from Wales. Well, it's happening now, and upon reflectioon, it's fantastic that the medium of DVD has captured it.Here we go, with Part Two. The show itself is flawless, all aspects Emmy-worthy. The audio and video chromatics are spectacular. Technical direction is a lesson to those "youngers" with the hyperactive edit command. Keep three cameras rolling and....guess what? Point a lens at that big blon' babe in the second row. {Sexist, yeah, yeah.....).This package has many highlights: for the unitiated, beyond-belief renditions of "You'll Never Walk Alone" and "It's A Man's, Man's Man's World" [finale mini-concert pieces]; a time-capsule encounter with a 34 year-old "Killer" [aka JLL] - and maybe the best "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On" you've ever heard by this Sun Records originator. Jones' admiration for the Ferriday Fireball is obvious.Seems that the producers focused heavily on those names which have obviously time-traveled well: Sammy Davis, Jr. [what an incredible impression of Billy Eckstine!]; Tony Bennett; Liza Minelli; Pat Cooper; Jerry Lee Lewis; Johnny Cash.The great Bobby Darin is in a folky mood, in a pre-Springsteen era denim outfit, looking relaxed as "Bob Darin". He does a nice solo shot playing a typical-for-the-time introspective beat ballad - it's okay - wonder what a duet on "Dream Lover" might have sounded like, though.Diahann Carroll is absolutely stunning - all she had to do was stand in the spotlight for three minutes and no one would have objected, but she does a nice arrangement of "Traces"/"You've Lost That Lovin' Feeling".Comedy relief by the Ace Trucking Company, sporadically hilarious, with one thud; David Steinberg - apparently found his niche as big-time Producer. At this time he was lower than low-key "hip" comedian for the Woodstock generation - minus zero mirth content.
